title: The rise and fall of the medieval Islamic Empire - Petra Sijpesteijn & Birte Kristiansen

multiple-choice.question: Who united the people of the Arabian Peninsula through the formation of Islam?
Who emerged as the first caliph after Muhammad's death?
What was the name of the dynasty that came to power after the Umayyad caliphate was overthrown?
Where did the Abbasid family relocate the capital after overthrowing the Umayyad caliphate?
What was the result of the Mongols' destruction of Baghdad in 1258 CE?
What was the main cause of the decline of the Abbasid caliphate?
What was the impact of the written and spoken Arabic on the world?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to the decline of other languages

options.label: B
options.text: It left a lasting mark on the world

options.label: C
options.text: It had no impact on the world

options.label: D
options.text: It led to the spread of Islam

multiple-choice.question: Who were the people that benefited from the extensive trade networks in Baghdad?
What was the result of the caliph's dependence on his entourage to stay in power?
What was the outcome of the time of one united Islamic Empire?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a period of great prosperity

options.label: B
options.text: It was a period of great decline

options.label: C
options.text: It was a period of great conflict

options.label: D
options.text: It was a period of great unity

title: Can you guess what's wrong with these paintings? - Noah Charney

multiple-choice.question: What was the reason for altering "An Allegory with Venus and Cupid" by Bronzino?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the painting more attractive

multiple-choice.question: Who attributed the painting "Portrait of a Young Woman" to?
What was the method used to recreate the missing sections of "The Night Watch"?
What was the reason for removing strips from "The Night Watch" in 1715?

options.label: A
options.text: To fit it inside a smaller frame

options.label: C
options.text: To fit it inside Amsterdam's Town Hall

multiple-choice.question: What was the role of the museum guard in the restoration of "The Night Watch"?
What was the result of the restoration of "Portrait of a Young Woman"?

options.label: B
options.text: The painting was left with significant damage

multiple-choice.question: Who supported the video on the restoration and preservation of paintings?
What was the reason for altering "Portrait of a Young Woman"?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the subject more attractive

multiple-choice.question: What was the method used to remove the overpainting from "An Allegory with Venus and Cupid"?
What was the result of the restoration of "The Night Watch"?

options.label: B
options.text: The painting was left with significant damage

options.label: C
options.text: The painting was returned to its full size

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary language spoken by the Romans in the Iberian Peninsula?

Which language is often considered a mixture of Spanish and English?

title: Why a sausage can do what your gloves cannot - Charles Wallace and Sajan Saini

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary reason for the invention of the first touchscreen in 1965?

options.label: A
options.text: To help British air traffic controllers update flight plans efficiently.

options.label: C
options.text: To develop a new type of display technology.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a more user-friendly interface.

multiple-choice.question: What type of touchscreen dominated the market before the release of the iPhone in 2007?
What is the primary difference between conductors and insulators?

options.label: A
options.text: Conductors have a higher electrical resistance than insulators.

options.label: B
options.text: Conductors have a lower electrical resistance than insulators.

options.label: C
options.text: Conductors are made of a different material than insulators.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the thin insulating layer in a capacitive touchscreen?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the sensitivity of the screen.

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce the electrical resistance of the screen.

options.label: C
options.text: To separate the conductive lines from the columns.

options.label: D
options.text: To protect the screen from damage.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the nodes in a capacitive touchscreen?

options.label: B
options.text: To increase the sensitivity of the screen.

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the electrical resistance of the screen.

options.label: D
options.text: To protect the screen from damage.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why gloves can interfere with a capacitive touchscreen?

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are made of a different material than the screen.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of water on a capacitive touchscreen?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the sensitivity of the screen.

options.label: B
options.text: It reduces the electrical resistance of the screen.

options.label: C
options.text: It can trigger multiple nodes and cause the screen to act as if multiple parts are being touched.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on the screen.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why the iPhone's release led to the dominance of capacitive touchscreens?
What is the primary difference between resistive and capacitive touchscreens?

options.label: A
options.text: Resistive touchscreens use a different type of material than capacitive touchscreens.

options.label: B
options.text: Resistive touchscreens are more sensitive than capacitive touchscreens.

options.label: C
options.text: Resistive touchscreens require more force to activate than capacitive touchscreens.

options.label: D
options.text: Resistive touchscreens are less durable than capacitive touchscreens.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why snack sausages were used as makeshift gloves in 2010?

options.label: C
options.text: Because they were made of a different material than the screen.

title: This weird trick will help you summon an army of worms - Kenny Coogan

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the tradition in which a metal strip is slid over a wooden stake to produce a deep croaking noise, causing earthworms to emerge from the soil?
Who proposed the hypothesis that worms were charmed by the noise, like the rats from the medieval Pied Piper legend?
What was the result of Kenneth Catania's experiments in 2008, which tested the hypothesis that worm grunting mimicked falling rain?

options.label: A
options.text: The worms emerged from the soil

options.label: C
options.text: The worms were charmed by the noise

options.label: D
options.text: The worms were tickled by the vibrations

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of Charles Darwin's final work, published in 1881, which discussed the habits of earthworms?

options.label: A
options.text: The Formation of Vegetable Mould, Through the Action of Worms

multiple-choice.question: What did Kenneth Catania find in his experiments with Eastern moles?

options.label: B
options.text: They were abundant in the Florida Panhandle

options.label: C
options.text: They could eat their weight in worms every day

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Kenneth Catania's experiments when a mole was released into worm-filled arenas?

options.label: B
options.text: The worms emerged from the soil

options.label: C
options.text: The worms were charmed by the noise

options.label: D
options.text: The worms were tickled by the vibrations

multiple-choice.question: What do scientists think is the reason why the behavior of earthworms emerging from the soil persists?

options.label: A
options.text: It is beneficial for a prey species to maintain its adaptations against a more frequent predator

options.label: B
options.text: It is beneficial for a prey species to maintain its adaptations against a rarer predator

options.label: C
options.text: It is beneficial for a prey species to remain vulnerable to predators

options.label: D
options.text: It is beneficial for a predator to remain vulnerable to prey

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the bird that takes advantage of the behavior of earthworms emerging from the soil?
Who set the current world record for "most worms charmed" in 2009?
What was the method used by the 10-year-old British girl to charm the worms in 2009?

options.label: A
options.text: She slid a metal strip over a wooden stake

options.label: B
options.text: She wiggled a fork in the ground and hit it with a stick

options.label: C
options.text: She used a worm charmer's device

title: The true cost of gold - Lyla Latif

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated value of one kilogram of gold?
In 2020, Mali produced an estimated _______ tons of gold.
What is the main reason why Mali and other gold-rich countries in Africa are not seeing the expected income from gold mining?

options.label: B
options.text: Corruption and greed on individual, corporate, and national scales

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the taxes paid by multinational corporations to the government of Mali?

options.label: A
options.text: To finance the development of the country

options.label: B
options.text: To pay for the expenses of the corporations

options.label: C
options.text: To provide citizens with public goods such as healthcare and education

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the wealth of the government officials

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the tactics used by multinational corporations to avoid paying taxes?

options.label: C
options.text: Buying gold on the black market

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the country where Mali's gold is often smuggled to?
What is the estimated amount of gold exported by Mali in 2016?
What is the main reason why Mali's revenue authority cannot verify the information provided by the corporations about their expenses?

options.label: B
options.text: Corruption and greed on individual, corporate, and national scales

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of the gold smuggling on the economy of Mali?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the wealth of the country

options.label: C
options.text: It creates a vicious cycle of poverty

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on the economy

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They are living below the international poverty line

options.label: D
options.text: They are living in extreme poverty

title: The 4 greatest threats to the survival of humanity

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary driver of existential risk?
What is the estimated anthropogenic existential risk compared to the background rate of natural risk?
What is the potential consequence of a global nuclear war?

options.label: B
options.text: A nuclear winter that blocks out the sun for years

options.label: D
options.text: No significant impact on human civilization

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary concern with engineered pandemics?

options.label: C
options.text: The potential for biowarfare and research accidents

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential consequence of unaligned artificial intelligence?

options.label: C
options.text: A potential existential risk if it isn't perfectly aligned with human values

options.label: D
options.text: No significant impact on human civilization

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated rate of natural existential risk per century?
What is the potential consequence of climate change?

options.label: C
options.text: A potential calamity of unprecedented proportions

options.label: D
options.text: No significant impact on human civilization

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary driver of the increase in existential risk?

options.label: A
options.text: The invention of the atomic bomb

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated anthropogenic existential risk compared to the background rate of natural risk?
What is the potential consequence of treating safeguarding humanity's future as a defining issue?

options.label: A
options.text: A small increase in existential risk

options.label: B
options.text: No significant impact on human civilization

options.label: D
options.text: An increase in human choices and actions

title: What causes yeast infections, and how do you get rid of them? - Liesbeth Demuyser

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of Lactobacilli in the human vagina?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce an acidic environment that limits the growth of other microorganisms

options.label: B
options.text: To secrete enzymes that degrade the epithelial cells lining the vagina

options.label: C
options.text: To cause infections and disrupt the balance of the vaginal microbiome

options.label: D
options.text: To produce hormones that regulate the menstrual cycle

multiple-choice.question: What is the most common cause of vaginal yeast infections?
What happens when the balance of the vaginal microbiome is disrupted?

options.label: A
options.text: Candida yeasts become harmless and the body's immune system can control them

options.label: B
options.text: Candida yeasts assume their disease-causing forms and multiply

options.label: C
options.text: Lactobacilli become more prevalent and outcompete Candida

options.label: D
options.text: The vaginal pH becomes more alkaline and Candida cannot survive

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary symptom of a vaginal yeast infection?
What can contribute to the development of vaginal yeast infections?
What is the primary treatment for vaginal yeast infections?
What is the role of probiotics in treating vaginal yeast infections?

options.label: A
options.text: To reduce the number of Candida cells

options.label: B
options.text: To increase the number of Lactobacilli

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce inflammation and promote healing

options.label: D
options.text: To cause more Candida to grow

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated percentage of people with vaginas who experience at least 4 yeast infections a year?
What is one of the possible causes of recurrent vaginal yeast infections?
What is one of the reasons why research on vaginal yeast infections is limited?

title: The world’s slimiest animal - Noah R. Bressman and Douglas Fudge

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary defense mechanism of hagfish?

options.label: B
options.text: Spewing a stupendous supply of slime

options.label: C
options.text: Using their sharp teeth to bite predators

multiple-choice.question: How many slime glands line the hagfish's body?
What is the composition of hagfish slime?

options.label: B
options.text: Mucus and reinforced with superfine and strong silk-like fibers

multiple-choice.question: How quickly can hagfish produce slime?

options.label: B
options.text: In a fraction of a second

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of hagfish tying themselves in knots?

options.label: C
options.text: To wipe away their own slime

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential application of hagfish slime in athletic and safety gear?

options.label: D
options.text: To rival the properties of materials like nylon

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of hagfish in the deep sea ecosystem?

options.label: B
options.text: To clean the seafloor and cycle essential nutrients

options.label: D
options.text: To provide food for other marine animals

multiple-choice.question: How many hearts do hagfish have?
How long can hagfish survive without oxygen?
When did proto-hagfish first appear in the ocean?

title: What’s the best country to live in?

multiple-choice.question: What was the original purpose of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) when it was first invented by Simon Kuznets in the 1930s?

options.label: A
options.text: To measure a country's economic performance and influence various aspects of society.

options.label: B
options.text: To gauge the size of an economy in a single, easy-to-understand number.

options.label: C
options.text: To track a country's inflation rate.

options.label: D
options.text: To measure a country's trade balance.

multiple-choice.question: What is the total monetary value of everything a country produces and sells on the market?
What is the problem with using GDP per capita as a measure of well-being if a country's wealth is concentrated among a small percentage of the population?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides a more accurate picture of well-being.

options.label: B
options.text: It gives a distorted picture of how much money a typical person has.

options.label: C
options.text: It is not relevant to measuring well-being.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not a good indicator of economic growth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between GDP growth and wage growth in many countries since the 1980s?

options.label: A
options.text: Wages have grown proportionally with GDP growth.

options.label: B
options.text: Wages have stopped keeping pace with GDP growth, or in some cases, have declined.

options.label: C
options.text: Wages have increased at a faster rate than GDP growth.

options.label: D
options.text: Wages have decreased at a faster rate than GDP growth.

multiple-choice.question: What is Gross National Happiness, and what is its alternative to GDP?

options.label: A
options.text: A metric that factors in health, education, and living standards to estimate overall well-being.

options.label: B
options.text: A metric that takes into account income per capita and education to estimate overall well-being.

options.label: C
options.text: A metric that factors in health, education, strong communities, and living standards, having citizens answer questions about their well-being.

options.label: D
options.text: A metric that takes into account environmental sustainability and income per capita to estimate overall well-being.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following countries has made significant progress in balancing economic growth and sustainability?
What is the main limitation of relying on a single number to measure a country's well-being?

options.label: A
options.text: It does not account for non-market activities.

options.label: B
options.text: It can provide a distorted picture of well-being if a country's wealth is concentrated among a small percentage of the population.

options.label: C
options.text: It does not take into account environmental sustainability.

multiple-choice.question: What is the preferred approach to measuring a country's well-being among experts?

options.label: B
options.text: A dashboard approach that presents multiple factors.

options.label: C
options.text: A combination of both single number and dashboard approaches.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the metric that factors in both well-being and the environmental burdens of economic growth?
Which country has better well-being outcomes like life expectancy than some of the world's richest countries?

title: What happens to your body at the top of Mount Everest - Andrew Lovering

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the air at high altitudes?

options.label: A
options.text: The air gets thicker and more humid.

options.label: B
options.text: The air remains the same as at sea level.

options.label: C
options.text: The air gets thinner and has less oxygen.

options.label: D
options.text: The air gets colder and more windy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the initial response of the body to low oxygen levels at high altitudes?

options.label: A
options.text: The body decreases heart rate and breathing rate.

options.label: B
options.text: The body increases heart rate and breathing rate.

options.label: C
options.text: The body remains the same as at sea level.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to hemoglobin levels in the blood over time at high altitudes?

options.label: B
options.text: Hemoglobin levels remain the same as at sea level.

multiple-choice.question: What is the process by which the body adapts to high altitudes over time?
What are the two conditions that can occur at high altitudes and can be life-threatening if not treated promptly?
What is the genetic advantage that some individuals, such as Tibetans and South Americans, have that helps them adapt to high altitudes?
What happens to the blood vessels in the brain at high altitudes?
What is the result of the increased pressure on the blood vessels at high altitudes?
What is the process by which the body increases breathing rate at high altitudes?
What is the result of the body's adaptations to high altitudes over time?

options.label: A
options.text: The body remains the same as at sea level.

options.label: B
options.text: The body adapts to high altitudes.

title: The British Museum is full of stolen artifacts

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of cultural and historical artifacts housed in the British Museum?

options.label: A
options.text: To collect cultural and historical artifacts

options.label: B
options.text: To take revenge on the Kingdom of Benin

options.label: C
options.text: To destroy the kingdom and take thousands of artifacts

options.label: D
options.text: To establish a trade agreement with the kingdom

multiple-choice.question: What is the current stance of the British Museum regarding the return of artifacts?

options.label: A
options.text: It returns objects to their rightful owners

options.label: B
options.text: It does not return objects but lends them widely

options.label: C
options.text: It sells artifacts to raise funds for the museum

options.label: D
options.text: It destroys artifacts that are deemed valuable

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the group formed in 2007 to discuss potential solutions for the return of the Benin Bronzes?
What is the estimated number of contested items in the British Museum?
What is the main issue with the British Museum's collection, according to some critics?

options.label: C
options.text: It still behaves like a colonial museum

options.label: D
options.text: It does not have enough artifacts from Africa

title: Why can parrots talk? - Grace Smith-Vidaurre and Tim Wright

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the vocal anatomy of parrots compared to other birds?

options.label: A
options.text: Parrots have two vibrating membranes in their syrinx.

options.label: B
options.text: Parrots have just one vibrating membrane in their syrinx.

options.label: C
options.text: Parrots have a larger syrinx than other birds.

options.label: D
options.text: Parrots have a smaller syrinx than other birds.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why parrots are able to mimic human speech?

options.label: A
options.text: Their ability to mimic human speech is due to their large brain size.

options.label: B
options.text: Their ability to mimic human speech is due to their unique vocal anatomy.

options.label: C
options.text: Their ability to mimic human speech is due to their social behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to mimic human speech is due to their physical characteristics.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the region in a parrot's brain that allows it to hear, remember, modify, and produce complex sounds?
What is the name of the African grey parrot that became the first non-human animal to pose an existential question?
Why are parrots vulnerable to poaching, pet trading, and habitat loss?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are highly social birds.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are valuable and sought after by humans.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are found in large colonies.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why parrots use their tongues and beaks to shape sounds into enunciated words?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have a unique vocal anatomy.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are highly social birds.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they have flexible and powerful tongues.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the parrot species that has individualized contact calls that help them stand out in large colonies?

options.label: D
options.text: The parrot species has no individualized contact calls.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the region in a parrot's brain that allows it to understand the meaning of words and use them in context?
What is the main reason why parrots are able to produce a wide range of sounds, including the human voice?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have a unique vocal anatomy.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are highly social birds.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they have flexible and powerful tongues.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the parrot species that was observed to say things in the appropriate contexts and assign meaning to words?

options.label: D
options.text: The parrot species has no observed language abilities.
